newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds open weaker, underperform on soft dlr.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds open weaker, underperform on soft dlr.

text.p: Canadian bonds opened weaker on Friday, with spreads to U.S. long bonds widening as weakness in the Canadian dollar weighed on prices, analysts said.

"I think what's happening here is a little bit of worry now about the Canadian dollar and the implications that might have on the Canadian bond market," said Michael Gregory, a fixed-income economist and strategist with Lehman Brothers Canada Inc.
Canada's 30-year benchmark fell C$0.45 to C$107.57 to yield 7.343 percent.
The U.S. 30-year bond fell 4/32 to yield 7.14 percent. The spread between the two bonds widened to 20 basis points from 18 basis points at the close of trading on Thursday.

The Canadian dollar opened easier at C$1.3954 (US$0.7166) on Friday from Thursday's close of C$1.3923 (US$0.7182) as U.S. interest rate hike fears resurfaced and investors became jittery ahead of an expected Canadian federal election call.
Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien is widely expected to call an election this weekend for June 2.

"Yesterday's comments by the Fed official have sort of raised again the prospects for a Fed move. People are getting nervous about the two big (U.S.) reports next week, the employment cost index and the payroll numbers, and also, there's a lot of buzz now about the election," said Gregory.
Dealers said trading in both Canadian and U.S. fixed-income markets is expected to remain light until next week when the reports on U.S. employment costs and employment growth are released.
In other prices, the Canadian 10-year benchmark bond fell C$0.35 to C$101.33 to yield 6.807 percent. The U.S. bond fell 2/32 to yield 6.94 percent.
The negative spread between the bonds narrowed to 13 basis points from 18 basis points on Thursday.
The three-month cash T-bill yielded 3.17 percent against its U.S. equivalent which yielded 5.31 percent.
